node.title: Waikato biggest loser as doctors, nurses and midwives stood down across country
node.description: District health boards are operating without 470 nurses because they have not been vaccinated.

node.title: Money moves you can use to help ward off inflation
node.description: With prices on the rise, financial experts offer tips for how to save money, cut costs and invest wisely.

node.title: This is who scholars believe really killed Malcolm X.
node.description: The review by the Manhattan district attorney’s office did not pin the crime on any other suspects. But scholars have formed their own conclusions.

node.title: ‘Then I Felt a Tap on My Shoulder’
node.description: A sad moment as dusk falls, from this week's Metropolitan Diary

node.title: New Delhi Considers Lockdown, But Not for COVID, as Smog Chokes City of 20 Million
node.description: Smog covered the Indian city of New Delhi where air particles were seven times higher than what the World Health Organization deemed as safe levels.

node.title: COVID Lockdowns Saw Global Increase in Helpline Calls About Loneliness, Suicide: Report
node.description: Researchers determined that the number of calls was highest at six weeks into the pandemic in 2020, and 35 percent higher than the same period in the year prior.

node.title: TikToker Who Called out of Work Sick Caught on Camera at NBA Game in Viral Video
node.description: "I don't believe a boss should be mad over that. Our life doesn't belong to any company," one comment read.

node.title: Viral Video Showing a Surveillance Camera Visible in Fitting Room Mirror Sparks Debate
node.description: "Wow I'm so mad, I literally noticed when I was putting my clothes back on," reads the video's text overlay.

node.title: Endangered curlews feed here at the end of their epic migration, but a retirement village may be built next door
node.description: Critics say a plan to develop a retirement village next to endangered bird habitat will further jeopardise a species in decline, but the developers say they're being made scapegoats.

node.title: Borders are reopening and COVID is coming. What can Tasmanians expect?
node.description: It's a message Tasmania's Premier Peter Gutwein has been driving home: COVID will enter Tasmania when borders open next month. So when and where is the state likely to have an outbreak?

node.title: Sam is trapped in Katherine as COVID cases grow. And he's not the only one
node.description: As Katherine grapples with the NT's biggest COVID-19 outbreak to date, Sam Ashley has been sleeping on a patch of grass near the river.

node.title: Private security could soon guard secretive naval communications base instead of AFP
node.description: One of the country's most secretive and important military facilities, which helps support Australian and US naval operations, could soon be guarded by private security personnel, rather than federal police.

node.title: Childcare 'crisis situation' as vaccine mandates force some workers out
node.description: Childcare centre operators say fee hikes at some centres are inevitable as mandates for COVID-19 vaccinations around the country force them to terminate some staff and put others on leave.

node.title: Cash hoarders stuffed record amounts under mattresses during pandemic
node.description: Before the pandemic, there were about $80 billion in notes circulating in Australia. Now there's $100 billion — but it's not in cash registers.

node.title: Kate's abusive ex racked up almost $86k of debt in her name. This is how she got help
node.description: Shortly after domestic violence survivor Kate left her husband, the banks started chasing her to repay debts in her name. It was not until she got help from a lawyer and financial counsellor that she realised there was a way out.

node.title: The cleanest jet fuel has an explosive history. Would you board a hydrogen plane?
node.description: As the world looks for new ways to combat climate change, hydrogen has emerged as a potential saviour for polluting industries like aviation. But will it work?

node.title: Why and how books get challenged
node.description: Parents have the right to petition school boards to remove books — but censorship is also a First Amendment issue.

node.title: Park Avenue Armory Announces Futuristic New Season
node.description: Highlights include the North American premieres of Michel van der Aa’s opera “Upload” and Robert Icke’s production of “Hamlet.”

node.title: CEO of World's Largest Crypto Exchange Says It's Time the Industry Gets Some Rules
node.description: Binance CEO Changpeng Zhao feels it is "the right time" to introduce regulations into the cryptocurrency industry.

node.title: Gas Trade Group Calls Biden's Demand for Probe a 'Distraction' Amid Misconduct Accusations
node.description: The president asked the FTC to investigate whether Americans are paying more for gas "because of anti-competitive or otherwise potentially illegal conduct."

node.title: Starbucks Employee Slammed for Filming 'Racist' TikTok While on the Job in Viral Clip
node.description: According to the company's official guidelines, "You must not promote any political or personal views or beliefs on or around Starbucks premises."

node.title: Court only avenue for alleged victims to prove claims against nurse James Griffin
node.description: The Tasmanian Health Service has not admitted to the abuse by Launceston nurse James Griffin claimed by the three plaintiffs, as court documents detail new information about concerns raised at the hospital about his conduct.

node.title: William Tyrrell strategy 'lacking in early days' but valuable lessons helped find Cleo Smith, expert says
node.description: A leading criminologist says some of the reasons William Tyrrell hasn't been found in seven years helped police in Western Australia locate missing girl Cleo Smith after 18 days.

node.title: Disney Cruise Line will require all passengers ages 5 and older to be fully vaccinated.
node.description: The mandate will go into effect on Jan. 13 and will apply to sailings both in the United States and abroad.

node.title: New Year’s Eve Will Return to Times Square for Vaccinated Guests
node.description: The event will return at “full strength” after pared-back festivities last year, Mayor Bill de Blasio said. People will have to show proof that they are fully vaccinated to attend.

node.title: The White House estimates nearly 10 percent of younger children have gotten a first shot.
node.description: Last week alone, 1.7 million young children were vaccinated, about double the previous week, a White House official said.

node.title: Young U.S. Men's Soccer Team Sees Path Back to World Cup After Missing Last One
node.description: After not qualifying for the 2018 FIFA World Cup, the U.S. men's national team needs three more home wins to qualify for the 2022 event.

node.title: In New Rules, U.S. Catholic Bishops Sidestep Direct Answer on Who Is Allowed Communion
node.description: The proposed document has generated controversy since the bishops' assembly first decided to begin drafting it in June.

node.title: Rittenhouse Judge Says He Allowed Defendant to Pick Jurors to Protect 'Optics'
node.description: Judge Bruce Schroeder said ever since he tried a case with "bad optics" around picking which jurors would deliberate, he has had the "almost universal policy."

node.title: 'It hurts, but it's a good thing': Human remains discovered in Pike River mine
node.description: A turbulent mix of emotions are being felt as - just two days shy of the 11th anniversary of the Pike River mine disaster- human remains have been discovered.

node.title: ‘The Antelope Party’ Review: Friendship Is Magic, With Exceptions
node.description: Paranoia takes root among five friends who fear their “My Little Pony” role playing game is being targeted in this new play at the Wild Project.

node.title: They Love Crypto. They’re Trying to Buy the Constitution.
node.description: How a “financial flash mob” is trying to raise $20 million for a rare copy of the U.S. Constitution.

node.title: A new witness supports the original alibi of one of the wrongfully convicted men.
node.description: The witness is an 80-year-old Brooklyn resident who answered the telephone at the Nation of Islam Mosque in Harlem the day Malcolm X was killed.

node.title: A timeline of major events in the case since Malcolm X’s death.
node.description: Uncertainties about who really killed Malcolm X have plagued the case since 1965.

node.title: ICC to study Afghanistan situation
node.description: The International Cricket Council has set up a working group to determine the future of the game in Afghanistan under the Taliban government.

node.title: Greece to Put Aid Workers Who Helped Migrants on Trial on Espionage Charges
node.description: The country’s conservative government is toughening its stance on migration and on groups working with migrants, aligning itself with a hardening climate across Europe.

node.title: Popular European Destinations That Unvaccinated People Can and Can't Travel To
node.description: Several European countries have placed travel restrictions on unvaccinated travelers from the United States.

node.title: Why Smallpox Is so Dangerous As Vials Found in Pennsylvania
node.description: The FBI and CDC are investigating after 15 vials labeled "smallpox" were discovered at a lab outside Philadelphia.

node.title: Radioactive Water From Fukushima Plant Would Have Small Environmental Impact: Operator
node.description: Japan planned to release treated radioactive water in the spring of 2023 after data simulation said there's little environmental impact. Experts aren't so sure.

node.title: Bear Cub Plays in Snow for the First Time in Adorable Video

node.title: Watch NHL Player Kevin Hayes Honor Late Brother Jimmy After Scoring First Goal of Season
node.description: After scoring the goal, Hayes said that he planned to give the puck to his brother's son, Beau.

node.title: Judge in Ahmaud Arbery Trial Again Denies Defense Mistrial, Ban of High-Profile Visitors

node.title: Monarch Butterflies Return to California in Large Numbers After Last Year's Historic Low
node.description: Pacific Grove in California is one of the many areas the butterflies are expected to land during the winter.

node.title: Justus Rosenberg, Beloved Professor With a Heroic Past, Dies at 100
node.description: As a teenager, he helped provide safe passage to artists and intellectuals out of Vichy France. He went on to teach literature at Bard College for six decades.

node.title: Philip Margo of the Tokens, Who Sang of a Snoozing Lion, Dies at 79

node.title: The Secret to Great Online Communities
node.description: Our online experiences are shaped by the people who run our favorite Facebook group or Reddit forum.

node.title: Oklahoma Governor and Pentagon Standoff Over Vaccines Intensifies
node.description: The state says its National Guard members don’t need to get vaccinated. Pentagon officials say a failure to follow “valid medical readiness requirements” could “jeopardize” the status of troops.

node.title: Sudanese forces kill 10 protesting the country’s recent coup, medics report.

node.title: Steve Bannon's Lawyer Decries 'Vindictive' Prosecution by Jan 6. Committee

node.title: Lobster Harvesting Ban Reinstated Off Maine Coast in Effort to Protect Rare Whales

node.title: In the suburbs of Melbourne, Logan felt a void in his life. He filled it with fire

node.title: With a federal election looming, the Great Resignation presents politicians with big opportunities

node.title: Inmate Whose 1963 Case Later Led to Freedom for Teen Offenders Finally Granted Parole

node.title: TSA head expects busy but "smooth" holiday travel season
node.description: Experts fear that a possible staff shortage could lead to long security lines at U.S. airports, which are expected to see up to 80% more travelers compared with last year.

node.title: Fatal Surfside Condo Collapse Occurred Due to Construction of High-Rise Next Door: Lawsuit

node.title: Drug crisis, corruption and COVID-19 on voters' minds as Tonga heads to the polls

node.title: As the NT's COVID outbreak grows, so are questions about why this at-risk community isn't in lockdown
node.description: Pressure is growing on the NT government to declare a lockdown in Borroloola, a large remote community with strong links to Robinson River where six Aboriginal people have so far tested positive to COVID amid a Territory cluster.

node.title: The same places keep appearing in most-disadvantaged lists. COVID means it could be getting worse
node.description: The most comprehensive report into disadvantage in Australia reveals disadvantage is not only entrenched in some communities, it also impacts a wide range of factors.

node.title: Covid-19 wrap: Auckland on path to reopening, vaccine pass launched
node.description: Schools have reopened for younger students, the Auckland boundary is set to reopen mid-December for a month, and a Covid-19 vaccine pass has come into play.

node.title: Bishops approve Communion guidelines after debate on Biden's eligibility

node.title: She Shaped the Sound of ‘Cowboy Bebop,’ Again

node.title: What if Your Kids Never Let You Sleep Again?

node.title: 2 Men Convicted of Killing Malcolm X Will Be Exonerated After 55 Years

node.title: Does Your Dog Deserve a Private Park?
node.description: When no ordinary fire hydrant will do, New York City offers multiple members-only dog parks, for annual fees ranging from free to $2,200.

node.title: Catholic Bishops Avoid Confrontation With Biden Over Communion
node.description: In a vote, they endorsed new guidance on offering holy communion to public figures but did not overtly mention the president or other officials who support abortion rights.

node.title: U.S. Journalist Danny Fenster 'Incredibly Fortunate' to Be Home After Myanmar Imprisonment
node.description: "I can't believe the amount of effort that went into it that was necessary to make this happen–overwhelming gratitude," Fenster said.

node.title: Woman Says She Woke Up With Bite Marks After Passing Out at Club in Viral Video

node.description: Adams also brought several packs of rolling papers and a blanket as gifts for Stephen Colbert.

node.description: Jason Wedderburn joins his co-conspirator, Kayan Kitson, in jail after being sentenced to three years.

node.description: The iconic holiday armadillo outfit worn by Ross Geller, played by David Schwimmer, appears in season 7 , episode 10.

node.title: QAnon Shaman Jacob Chansley, Who Asked Trump for Pardon, Gets 41 Months for Capitol Riot
node.description: Chansley denied he's a "dangerous criminal," an "insurrectionist" or a "domestic terrorist" but took responsibility for his actions during a court hearing.

node.title: Joe Biden Calls for Probe Into Whether Illegal Conduct Is to Blame for High Gas Prices
node.description: Today, the average price for a gallon of regular unleaded gas is $3.413—more than a dollar higher than the average price one year ago.

node.title: Trump Tells McConnell to Resign if Biden Social Bill Passes, Vows to Withhold Endorsements
node.description: Trump, who threatened to withhold endorsements from Congressional Republicans, called McConnell a "fool" who should have resigned a "long time ago."

node.title: Fijian Drua could play at home in 2022
node.description: The Fijian Drua could yet play on home soil in the inaugural campaign in Super Rugby Pacific.

node.title: Body found in Clutha River believed to be missing Alexandra man Wayne Hammond
node.description: Police found the body in the Clutha River in Central Otago about 1.5km from the Roxburgh Dam.

node.title: Biogen’s Alzheimer’s drug is unlikely to win E.U. approval.
node.description: The drug, Aduhelm, has been mired in controversy since it was in approved in the United States in June.

node.title: The Wisconsin National Guard has been placed on standby ahead of the verdict.

node.title: Pentagon Chief Expected to Discuss 2019 Airstrike That Killed Dozens

node.title: Scientists Warn of Bacterial 'Alien Invasion' Caused by Space Missions
node.description: Space missions could also carry "bacterial invaders" to unspoiled alien worlds such as Mars and the moon.

node.title: Judge Rules Refugee Can Be Deported for Lying About ISIS Involvement on Immigration Papers
node.description: A federal judge ruled Omar Abdulsattar Ameen is eligible for deportation to Iraq or Turkey after lying about having contact with anyone from terrorist groups.

node.title: Texas Library Cancel Children's Event After Transgender Misinformation Sparks Threats
node.description: Denton Public Library has defended its decision to initially hold the Rainbow StoryTime event despite backlash due to "incorrect information."

node.title: Mississippi to Conduct First Execution Since 2012, Inmate Calls Himself 'Worthy of Death'
node.description: David Cox, who murdered his estranged wife, is scheduled for execution by lethal injection at 6 p.m. CST at the Mississippi State Penitentiary at Parchman.

node.title: NFL Mandates New Testing Protocol Amid Uptick in COVID Cases, Holiday Season
node.description: Regardless of vaccine status, players, coaches and other NFL personnel will be required to wear masks during the week after Thanksgiving.

node.title: 'She's alright': Queen makes first in-person engagement since hospitalisation last month
node.description: The 95-year-old monarch was forced to pull out of Remembrance Sunday services last weekend after suffering a sprained back, Buckingham Palace said.

node.title: U.S. Catholic bishops to vote on who should receive Communion
node.description: Bishops continue debating whether Catholic politicians like President Biden, who support abortion rights, should be barred from Communion.

node.title: Thanksgiving for Beginners
node.description: Need a little assistance? Eric Kim has seven recipes and an invaluable guide to get you through the meal.

node.title: In Central Italy, a Dance Party By the Sea
node.description: Last month at La Posta Vecchia, the hotelier Marie-Louise Sciò threw a rollicking reunion for friends and family.

node.title: The DNA of Roma People Has Long Been Misused, Scientists Reveal
node.description: An op-ed in Nature calls for higher ethical standards in the usage and analysis of genetic information from the Romani, a marginalized group in Europe.

node.title: Amazon, railing against high fees, will stop accepting Visa credit cards issued in Britain.
node.description: For years merchants have complained about transaction fees that eat into their revenue, but having Amazon take up the fight may ratchet up the pressure. The change will come into effect Jan. 19.
